definition[0]: worry that is caused by having to deal with a problem or work too hard over a long period of time
example[0]: I couldn’t look after him anymore; the strain was too much for me.
example[1]: Did you find the job a strain?
example[2]: the stresses and strains of police life
example[3]: The long working hours put a severe strain on employees.
example[4]: I could see that she was beginning to crack under the strain.
example[5]: The trial has been a terrible strain for both of us.
example[6]: It’s quite a strain on me when he’s drinking heavily.
example[7]: I know you’ve been under a lot of strain lately.
definition[1]: a difficulty or problem that is caused when a person, relationship, organization, or system has too much to do or too many problems to deal with
example[8]: The flu epidemic has put a huge strain on the health service.
example[9]: The party split under the strain.
example[10]: The dry summer has further increased the strain on water resources.
example[11]: The attack has led to strains in the relationship between the two countries.
definition[2]: a situation in which something is being pulled or pushed, or is holding weight, and so might break or become damaged
example[13]: These four posts take the strain of the whole structure.
example[14]: Some of these exercises put too much strain on the back muscles.
example[15]: The rope snapped under the strain.
example[16]: The strain on the cables supporting the bridge is enormous.
definition[3]: an injury to a muscle or part of your body that is caused by using it too much
example[17]: Long hours working at a computer can cause eye strain.
example[18]: The goalkeeper is still out of action with a knee strain.
definition[4]: a type of animal, plant, or disease
example[20]: a new strain of the flu virus
definition[5]: a particular quality which people have, especially one that is passed from parents to children
example[21]: There’s a strain of madness in his family.
definition[6]: an amount of a feeling that you can see in the way someone speaks, writes, paints etc
example[22]: a strain of bitterness in Young’s later work
example[23]: The country’s health system is under great strain.
example[25]: The cost of these wars put an intolerable strain on the economy.
example[26]: How much can you invest without putting any undue strain on your finances?
example[27]: She has been suffering from considerable emotional strain.
example[28]: This welfare program has eased the financial strain of raising children alone.
example[29]: Living with my parents put quite a strain on our marriage.
example[30]: They are worried that the court system might collapse under the strain.
example[31]: You can do much to ease the strain of the situation for her.
example[32]: Claudia could see that he was under considerable strain.
example[33]: Holidays help people to cope with the stresses and strains of life.
definition[7]: to injure a muscle or part of your body by using it too much or making it work too hard
example[34]: I’ve strained a muscle in my leg.
example[35]: You’ll strain your eyes trying to read in this light.
definition[8]: to try very hard to do something using all your strength or ability
example[36]: I strained my ears, listening for any sound in the silence of the cave.
example[37]: She was straining to keep her head above the water.
example[38]: Bill choked and gasped, straining for air.
definition[9]: to separate solid things from a liquid by pouring the mixture through something with very small holes in it
definition[10]: to cause difficulties for something by making too much work or too many problems which it cannot deal with easily
example[40]: The increased costs will certainly strain our finances.
example[41]: The incident has strained relations between the two countries.
example[42]: I felt that my patience was being strained to the limit.
definition[11]: to pull hard at something or push hard against something
example[43]: Buddy’s huge gut strained against the buttons on his shirt.
example[44]: a dog straining at its lead
